I. 

THE PROPOSAL  

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 
to  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  for  the  Xi’an  Urban  Road  Network  Improvement 
Project.1 
 
2. 
The  project  provides  an  opportunity  for  ADB  to  support  sustainable  urban  transport 
development  in  the  PRC.  The  project  will  finance  investment  in  road  network  improvements, 
pedestrian  mobility  and  safety,  multimodal  interchange  facilities,  intelligent  transport  system 
(ITS), and low emissions fuelling infrastructure. To support this project, an ADB-financed project 
preparatory  technical  assistance2  was  approved  in  2009  to  produce  an  agreed  design  and 
implementation arrangements for an urban transport project suitable for ADB financing.  
 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Xi’an, the provincial capital and economic and cultural center of Shaanxi Province, is one 
of the most important growth poles in the western region of the PRC. The city is expanding and 
developing rapidly and 72% of its 8.4 million residents in 2009 were categorized as urban. The 
urban  population  grew  at  an  annual  rate  of  2.5%  during  2000–2009  and  the  city’s  gross 
domestic product rose by 13.5% per annum over the same period. With this growth has come a 
rapid expansion of motorized vehicle traffic, along with the urban transport problems this often 
brings.  On  average,  the  number  of  vehicles  registered  in  Xi’an  increased  by  14.1%  a  year 
during  2003–2007.  Annual  passenger  vehicles  growth  was  21.8%.3  The  city  is  experiencing 
worsening  traffic  congestion  and  its  strategic  road  network,  especially  the  arterial  roads 
necessary  to  service  urban  expansion  between  its  Second  and  Third  ring  roads,  needs 
development to meet rising demand. The city’s transport system is poorly integrated and does 
not serve the needs of the entire community adequately or equitably. Roads are often unsafe for 
pedestrians and bicyclists. Air quality is deteriorating as vehicle emissions grow.  

4. 
Xi’an  is  trying  to  address  these  problems  by  expanding  its  road  network  and  transport 
infrastructure  and  services  with  its  own  financial  resources  and  support  from  the  Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)4  and  the  World  Bank.5  These  efforts  have  fallen  short  of  what  is 
needed to meet the growing volume of travel within the city, however. Economic and population 
growth and overcrowding within the historic walled city have led to increasing demand for new 
offices,  commercial  space,  and  social  infrastructure  in  urban  growth  poles  beyond  the  central 
area  in  the  band  between  the  Second  Ring  Road  and  the  Third  Ring  Road  on  the  city’s 
periphery. The change in traffic patterns and surging transport requirements that have resulted 
from  urban  growth  here,  combined  with  limited  existing  connectivity,  have  created  transport 
bottlenecks that could constrain the city’s further economic growth and development. The city’s 
master plan has identified the need to complete missing sections of its strategic road network to 
provide access to these emerging growth poles and to do so in a way that serves the needs of 
all road users, including public and private transport modes and pedestrians.

 2 

The city is finding it difficult to manage its overstretched transport system effectively. Its 
5. 
traffic  control  center  primarily  covers  only  areas  inside  the  Second  Ring  Road  and  lacks 
equipment  in  the  new  areas  of  urban  growth  beyond.  This  results  in  (i)  poor  system 
management,  (ii)  policing  and  enforcement  issues,  (iii)  conflict  between  vehicles  and 
pedestrians, and (iv) a system that fails to give proper priority to public transport and emergency 
vehicles.  

6. 
A lack of suitable equipment, capacity, and enforcement has also left Xi’an struggling in 
the  face  of  mounting  traffic  to  regulate  vehicle  standards,  driver  behavior,  and  emissions.  It 
needs more equipment to check the city’s motorized vehicle fleet for compliance with emissions 
standards and to monitor and report on these emissions, as it is required to do by national law. 
Greater vehicle-related emissions now account for 50% of poor ambient air quality, highlighting 
a need to develop the city’s capacity to manage and police its traffic better. 
 
7. 
To help address its transport challenges, Xi’an is expanding its public transport network 
to provide a more balanced range of travel choices and limit reliance on private vehicles. Two 
subway  lines  are  under  construction  and  four  more  are  in  development.  The  World  Bank  is 
supporting the establishment of 13 bus priority corridors, primarily inside the Second Ring Road. 
Public transport is made less attractive, however, by a lack of integration between its different 
modes and by the poor standard of the public transport connections to the areas beyond the old 
city center.  
 
8. 
Weaknesses in interagency coordination compound the city’s urban transport problems. 
They  also  contribute  to  the  lack  of  integration  between  various  modes  of  travel,  especially 
between the public transport and the nonmotorized modes most used by the poor, who walk or 
use bicycles for most of their trips.  
 
9. 
Addressing these complex, interrelated urban transport issues—and others, such as the 
growing  number  of  vehicle  collisions—will  require  a  concerted,  comprehensive  effort  over 
several  years.  The  Xi’an  authorities  recognize  that  a  holistic  approach  that  can  balance 
conflicting  pressures  and  demands  is  needed  to  provide  solutions  and  build  on  the  progress 
made through earlier ADB and World Bank assistance (footnotes 4 and 5). Lessons from past 
assistance  have  been  incorporated  into  the  project  design,  notably  the  need  for  improved 
coordination  between  line  agencies,  greater  emphasis  on  integrated  management  of  the 
transport system, and timely approval of resettlement plans. 
 
The  project  supports  the  PRC’s  search  for  suitable,  sustainable  solutions  to  its  urban 
10. 
transport problems and fits emerging urban priorities of its Twelfth Five-Year Plan, 2011–2015. 
It  is  also  focuses  the  key  development  agendas  of  inclusive  and  environmentally  sustainable 
development  under  ADB’s  Strategy  20206  and  aligns  with  the  proposed  PRC  country 
partnership  strategy  now  being  prepared.  By  addressing  urban  transport,  it  covers  one  of  the 
focus areas of ADB’s Sustainable Transport Initiative Operational Plan.7  
 
B. 

Impact and Outcome 

11. 
The impact will be support for inclusive,  environment-friendly economic growth in Xi’an 
by  facilitating  the  movement  of  goods  and  people.  By  contributing  to  comprehensive 

                                                      
6  ADB.  2008.  Strategy  2020:  The  Long-Term  Strategic  Framework  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank,  2008–2020. 

Manila. 

7  ADB. 2010. Sustainable Transport Initiative Operational Plan. Manila.  

 3 

improvement  of  integrated  urban  mobility  and  transport  system  management,  the  project  will 
support the continued economic growth of the city. The outcome will be an efficient, safe, and 
environmentally sustainable integrated urban transport system developed in Xi’an. 
 
C. 

Outputs 

12. 
The  project  will  provide  missing  road  links,  improved  interchanges,  bus  prioritization, 
nonmotorized  transport  routes,  better  pedestrian  safety,  multimodal  interchange  facilities, 
advanced traffic management, and vehicle emission control strategies. This will support better 
road  use  and  transport  access  for  all.  The  design  and  monitoring  framework  summarizes  the 
main features of the project (Appendix 1). The five project outputs are described below.  
 
Output  1:  Road  network  improvements.  Output  1  will  construct  and/or  rehabilitate 
13. 
12.92 kilometers (km) of urban roads along Keji 2nd Road (6.2 km), Kunming Road (4.39 km), 
and  Dazhai  West  Road  (2.33  km)  in  the  southwest  part  of  the  city.  These  roads  will  include 
21.57  km  of  bus  priority  corridors,  21.57  km  of  nonmotorized  transport  lanes,  and  a  4.2 km 
linear green park along Kunming Road. This output will also include six urban interchanges of 
suitable  sizes  and  configurations  at  current  critical  bottlenecks  on  the  road  network.  They  will 
provide sufficient access to the new urban growth centers between ring roads 2 and 3. The bus 
priority corridors will include lanes for the exclusive use of buses, traffic signals that give priority 
to  bus  transit,  station improvements,  and  traffic management  measures.  They  will  significantly 
improve  travel  conditions  for  bus  passengers.  The  roads  will  include  facilities  for  cyclists  and 
pedestrians as part of the project’s aim to have street design and traffic operations cater to all 
road  users.  The  road  network  improvements  will  provide  better  links  to  the  Second  and  Third 
ring roads, making them more functional, and improve road connections between the city’s new 
growth poles, the commercial business area in the southwest, and the government offices to the 
north. 
 
Output 2: Pedestrian crossing and safety improvements. Output 2 will upgrade 110 
14. 
urban  intersections  and  15  mid-block  pedestrian  crossing  facilities,  improving  crossing  signals 
and  visibility  and  safety  for  pedestrians.  Safety  equipment  using  advanced  information 
technology will be introduced and safety rules enforced. These improvements will promote the 
use  of  nonmotorized  transport,  make  it  safer,  and  better  serve  low-income  city  residents  who 
are unlikely to have access to private modes of transport and rely on walking or public transport. 
Women pedestrians on domestic errands and children are expected to benefit in particular.  
 
Output 3: Multimodal interchange facilities. Output 3 will construct (i) four multimodal 
15. 
transport hubs, (ii) five multilevel parking facilities, and (iii) five compressed natural gas (CNG) 
stations.  The  four  transport  hubs  (Xi’an  North  Train  Station,  Xi’an  National  Civil  Aerospace 
Industrial  Base,  Xi’an  Yuhua  Zhai,  and  Xi’an  International  Logistics  Park)  will  provide  easy 
connections between subway, bus, taxi, car, motorcycle, and bicycle travel. The hubs will thus 
link  other  transport  modes  from  and  to  the  surrounding  areas  with  key  public  transport  routes 
and provide staging and control facilities for public transport vehicles. The five multilevel parking 
facilities will provide off-street parking for 2,249 vehicles and for motorcycles and bicycles. Two 
will be built at the multimodal interchange facilities for Xi’an Yuhua Zhai and Xi’an International 
Logistics  Park  to  promote  modal  interchange  and  the  use  of  public  transport.  Three  parking 
garages will be located on the edge of the old walled city (Leju Chang, South Guoshang Village, 
and  Xizhan  Community).  This  will  help  manage  traffic  demand  by  allowing  motorized  vehicle 
users to park outside the city wall instead of driving into the congested central part of the city. 
The  parking  subcomponent  will  also  provide  parking  management  and  enforcement  on  the 
streets  around  the  parking  structures  and  address  the  serious  issue  of  illegal  parking  on 

 

 4 

sidewalks. One CNG station will be incorporated into each of the project multimodal interchange 
facilities and the fifth will be established close to the Third Ring Road at Mujiangwang. They will 
provide efficient fueling for buses, taxis, and private vehicles and encourage further switching to 
this  more  environmentally  sustainable  fuel  source.  Electric  charging  stations  will  also  be 
provided  at  the  multimodal  interchange  facilities  to  service  the  expected  growth  in  electric 
vehicles and an existing large fleet of electric motorcycles.  
 
16. 
Output 4: Intelligent transport system and road user safety program. Output 4 will 
extend the  coverage of the existing ITS to the Third Ring Road and the urban growth poles it 
serves.  It  will  also  develop  an  implementation  plan  for  improving  the  use  and  management  of 
the ITS; improve traveler information dissemination for both private and public transport modes; 
and  implement  a  road  safety  education  program  to  support  the  pedestrian  crossing  safety 
project  output,  including  toolkits,  training  materials,  and  safety  campaigns  targeted  at  such 
vulnerable road users as children and the elderly. This output includes capacity development to 
more effectively operate the ITS to achieve improved control of traffic and pedestrian crossings, 
as well as information dissemination and policing and enforcement. The output will include 20 
variable  traffic  message  signs,  140  microwave  detectors,  66  closed-circuit  televisions,  31  red-
light cameras, and 10 speed violation cameras.  
 
17. 
Output 5: Environmental protection enhancement. Output 5 will enhance the vehicle 
emissions  inspection  program  by  providing  random  inspection  capacity  and  five emission 
regulation  enforcement  vehicles,  10  black  smoke  stations, and  four  pieces  of  mobile  emission 
enforcement  equipment.  It  will  also  improve  air  quality  monitoring  by  establishing  four 
monitoring substations along the Third Ring Road equipped with air quality and noise monitoring 
systems connected to the environment information center and a remote sensing data receiving 
system  to  provide  city  wide  air  quality  status  in  the  city.  It  will  establish  a  computerized 
environment and vehicle emission information-sharing system, an emission regulation violation 
system,  public  sector  vehicle  management,  obsolete  vehicle  scrapping  enforcement 
administration assistance, and a system for environmental information disclosure. It will also set 
up an environmental information center. The city government is committed to raising the number 
of days each year that it records air quality better than grade II8 to more than 300 by reducing 
the emission of pollutants by industry, households, and vehicles. This output will help achieve 
that  commitment  by  supporting  more  effective  management  and  enforcement  of  vehicle 
standards.  
 
D. 

Investment and Financing Plans  

18. 
The  project  is  estimated  to  cost  $558.06  million  (including  taxes  and  duties  of 
$17.54 million).  The  government  requested  a  loan  of  $150  million  from ADB’s  ordinary  capital 
resources to finance 26.9% of the project cost. The loan will have a 25-year term, including a 
grace period of 5 years, an interest rate determined in accordance with ADB’s London interbank 
offered  rate  (LIBOR)-based  lending  facility,  a  commitment  charge  of  0.15%  per  annum,  and 
such terms and conditions as may be set forth in the draft loan and project agreements. ADB’s 
loan  will  cover  civil  works,  equipment,  project  management  consulting  services,  capacity 
building,  the  road user safety program,  and taxes and duties  on the expenditures  financed by

E. 

Implementation Arrangements 

The implementation arrangements are summarized in Table 3 and described in detail in 

20. 
the project administration manual.10 

21. 
The  executing  agency  will  be  the  Xi’an  Municipal  Urban  and  Rural  Construction 
Commission, which will have overall responsibility for project. The implementing agency will be 
the Xi’an Infrastructure Investment Group, which will be responsible for all project outputs and 
day-to-day  project 
implementation.  The  executing  agency  has  established  a  project 
management office (PMO) with suitable staff to report to the executing agency and coordinate 
and oversee project implementation. The PMO will (i)  ensure that the project activities comply 
with safeguard requirements; (ii) supervise procurement; (iii) monitor utilization of the ADB loan 
and the counterpart funding; (iv) prepare and submit reports to ADB and XMG; (v) ensure that 
complaints  received  from  the  project  stakeholders  are  addressed  adequately;  (vi)  submit 
progress, audit, and other reports to ADB; and (vii) coordinate with ADB review missions.  

22. 
The XMG has established a project leading group to address lessons from the previous 
ADB  project  (footnote  4).  It  will  be  responsible  for  project  oversight  and  ensuring  coordination 
across the various agencies that have responsibility for urban development and urban transport 
in Xi’an. The project leading group will be chaired by the vice mayor of the XMG, with heads of 
concerned  municipal  agencies  as  members.  The  vice  mayor  will  chair  project  leading  group 
meetings,  which  will  be  held  every  3  months  or  more  often  if  necessary  to  review

A. 

Technical 

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

The  capacity  of  XMG  to  deliver  and  in  the  operation  of  the  project  is  considered 
23. 
adequate to implement the project’s advanced technical aspects, based on its performance on 
such  aspects  in  the  past.  These  aspects  relate  to  the  multimodal  transport  facilities,  ITS, 
pedestrian safety, and environment outputs, as well as capacity and stakeholder involvement in 
system  operations  and  road  safety.  The  project  is  technically  viable  with  technology  choices 
based on efficient and proven designs. 
 
B. 

Economic and Financial 

24. 
The  project  is  economically  viable,  with  an  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return 
(EIRR) of 22.6% and net present value of CNY2,896.9 million discounted at 12%. The estimate 
covered  all  five  outputs  for  the  period  2011–2035.  The  estimated  costs  include  investment  in 
civil  works  and  equipment,  land  acquisition  and  resettlement,  and  periodic  operation  and 
maintenance (O&M). The estimated benefits include normal, generated, and diverted traffic and 
include  savings  in  vehicle  operating  cost,  travel  time,  and  reductions  in  road  accidents  and 
emissions.  Sensitivity  analysis  produced  a  favorable  EIRR  after  tests  assuming  cost  overruns 
and benefit reductions and showed that the project’s economic viability is robust.  
 
25. 
The  project  has  both  revenue  and  nonrevenue  components.  The  nonrevenue 
components include road network improvements, ITS upgrades, pedestrian crossing and safety 
improvements, environmental protection enhancement, and multimodal transport facilities. The 
two revenue-generating components consist of (i) the five CNG fueling stations, and (ii) the five 
parking facilities, which also include some revenue-producing retail space. The total estimated 

 

 

 8 

cost for the CNG stations is CNY62.6 million. O&M is estimated at CNY12.9 million (CNY12.3 
million after subtracting depreciation) per annum and is assumed to increase with inflation. The 
financial internal rate of return (FIRR) for the CNG stations component is 3.8%, which is higher 
than the weighted average cost of capital (WACC) of 1.6%. The financial net present value at 
this WACC is CNY15.6 million. The CNG stations are considered financially feasible. The total 
estimated  cost  of  the  five  multilevel  parking  structures  is  CNY137.2  million.  Annual  O&M  is 
estimated  at  CNY12.6  million  (CNY7.3  million  after  subtracting  depreciation)  at  the  start  of 
operation.  The  FIRR  for  the  parking  component  is  3.2%,  which  is  higher  than  the  WACC  of 
1.6%. The financial net present value at this WACC is CNY35.5 million. The multilevel parking 
garages are considered financially feasible. 

26. 
Annual  debt  service  and  O&M  are  forecast  to  be  about  0.5%  of  the  XMG’s  projected 
annual revenues in 2016 and to decline thereafter. Fiscal revenues of the municipal government 
will  grow  in  line  with  economic  development,  providing  more  resources  for  the  municipal 
government to finance the proposed project components. O&M and debt service for the project 
will account for about 3.4% of the Xi’an Infrastructure Investment Group’s projected revenues in 
2016 and will decline thereafter. This is considered adequate for the proposed loan. 
 
C. 

Governance  

All procurement to be financed under the ADB loan will be carried out in accordance with 
27. 
ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The relevant sections of 
the ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) will be included in all procurement 
document and contracts. ADB’s Anticorruption Policy was explained to and discussed with the 
Government  of  the  PRC,  the  XMG,  the  executing  agency  (including  the  PMO),  and  the 
implementing agency, including the project implementing unit. The specific policy requirements 
and supplementary measures are described in the project administration manual. 
 
D. 

Poverty and Social 

28. 
A  poverty  and  social  assessment  has  been  carried  out  in  accordance  with  the  ADB 
Handbook on Social Analysis.11 The assessment indicated that the project will contribute directly 
and indirectly to poverty reduction in Xi’an through the creation of an estimated 700 temporary 
job-years for construction and 300 permanent jobs for operation of the project outputs. Indirect 
benefits will accrue from lower health costs associated with reductions in vehicular emissions, 
road  accidents,  and  travel  times.  It  is  envisaged  that  the  project’s  largest  impact  will  be  the 
social benefits of making greater convenient, affordable, and safe transport options available in 
a  more  equitable  way  for  all  road  users,  including  women,  children,  the  elderly,  and  the 
disabled. Dedicated PMO staff will be responsible for implementation and monitoring of a social 
action plan that has been developed on the basis of the assessment’s findings.  
 
E. 

Safeguards 

29. 
Environment.  The  project  is  classified  under  environment  category  A.  In  compliance 
with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement (2009), an environmental impact assessment (EIA) was 
disclosed  on  ADB’s  website  on  24  June  2011  and  prepared  using  (i)  feasibility  study  reports, 
(ii) applicable  PRC  laws  and  requirements,  and  (iii)  a  cultural  relic  survey  report.  The  major 
potential environmental impacts involve emissions and noise from the increases in vehicle fleet 
size during the operational period. The project will address this through vehicle inspection and 

                                                      
11 ADB. 2007. Handbook on Social Analysis. Manila. 

 9 

enforcement  of  vehicle  emission  standards,  as  well  as  such  mitigation  measures  as  noise 
barrier  installation  where  noise  levels  exceed  standards  defined  in  the  environmental 
management  plan  (EMP).  While  no  significant  impacts  are  predicted  on  cultural  relic  sites, 
vibration  and  dust  will  be  closely  monitored  at  the  sites  during  construction,  a  cultural  relic 
expert  will  be  engaged  by  the  implementing  agency,  and  the  chance  finds  procedures  as 
defined in the EMP will be followed. 

30. 
XMG  will  be  required  to  observe  the  EIA  and  EMP  and  experience  from  past  ADB 
projects  indicate  that  it  has  the  capacity  to  properly  execute  the  plans.  To  ensure  all  potential 
adverse  environmental  impacts  of  the  project  are  mitigated,  the  implementing  agency  will 
implement  the  EMP  as  specified  in  the  EIA.  The  EMP  will  be  incorporated  in  the  bidding 
documents and contracts for civil works and monitored through semiannual reports submitted to 
ADB. A grievance redress mechanism has been developed, details of which are provided in the 
EIA.12 
 
31. 
Resettlement. The project is classified as category A for involuntary resettlement. The 
project will acquire 58.67 hectares (ha) of state-owned land. It will also acquire about 46.5 ha of 
collective  land,  of  which  10.2  ha  (22%)  is  classified  as  cultivated.  A  total  of  73,350  square 
meters  (m2)  of  residential  housing  and  267,257  m2  of  buildings  used  by  institutions  and 
enterprises will be demolished. The permanent land acquisition and house demolition required 
will affect 277 households and 9,576 people, including staff and workers. No land external to the 
project construction sites will be required for temporary use during construction. 
 
32. 
The cost of land acquisition and resettlement is CNY993 million. The executing agency 
has assured ADB that adequate counterpart funding will be made available for land acquisition 
and  resettlement,  in  line  with  the  annual  funding  requirements  stipulated  in  the  resettlement 
plan. Resettlement implementation will be monitored both internally and externally. Experience 
from  past  ADB  projects  indicates  that  the  executing  agency  has  the  institutional  capacity  to 
carry out the plan effectively. The PMO's land acquisition and resettlement unit will coordinate 
internal  supervision  and  reporting  of  plan  implementation  with  the  relevant  local  government 
agencies. The executing agency will engage an external institute for semiannual monitoring and 
reporting.  The  executing  agency  will  finance  all  of  the  monitoring  costs  from  their  counterpart 
funds. The monitoring details and costs are included in the resettlement plan.  
 
33. 
Indigenous peoples. As Han Chinese, who makes up the PRC’s majority ethnic group, 
comprises 99% of Xi’an’s population, the project is classified under category C. The remaining 
1% of the city’s residents is mostly Hui but no intrinsic difference exists in the way the project 
will  affect  the  two  ethnic  groups.  Both  will  benefit.  No  construction  activities  will  occur  near  a 
mosque,  the  most  common  place  of  religious  worship  for  the  predominantly  Muslim  Hui.  No 
ethnic  minority  people  have  been  identified  whose  assets  will  be  adversely  affected  by  the 
project. Measures to enhance the participation of the city’s Hui people are included in the social 
action plan.

in the assessment and risk management plan.13
